content.description: Reactive Attachment Disorder (RAD) is a trauma- and stressor-related disorder of early childhood characterized by markedly disturbed and developmentally inappropriate ways of relating socially. It occurs in children who have experienced extremes of insufficient care, leading to inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior toward adult caregivers and limited positive affect.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Consistent pattern of inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior toward adult caregivers, with both: (1) rarely/minimally seeking comfort when distressed, and (2) rarely/minimally responding to comfort when distressed. B. Persistent social and emotional disturbance with at least two of: minimal social/emotional responsiveness to others; limited positive affect; episodes of unexplained irritability, sadness, or fearfulness during nonthreatening interactions. C. The child has experienced extremes of insufficient care (e.g., social neglect/deprivation, repeated caregiver changes, rearing in settings limiting attachments). D. The care in Criterion C is presumed responsible for the disturbance. E. Criteria not met for Autism Spectrum Disorder. F. Evident before age 5. G. Developmental age at least 9 months. Specify if persistent (>12 months) and/or severe (all symptoms at high levels).
content.prevalence: Rare in the general population; most common among children who have experienced severe neglect, institutional rearing, or multiple foster placements.
content.age_of_onset: Emerges after 9 months of age and before age 5, when attachment should be established; often recognized in toddler/preschool years.
content.prognosis: With early, stable, nurturing caregiving, many children show significant improvement; untreated, may lead to ongoing relational difficulties, emotional dysregulation, and risk for other psychiatric disorders.

history: Comprehensive developmental, medical, and social history including neglect, institutional care, or caregiver changes.
Timeline of attachment-related behaviors and emotional withdrawal.
Quality and consistency of caregiving relationships.
observation_assessment: Direct observation of caregiver–child interactions across contexts.
Use of standardized attachment assessments and caregiver interviews.
Reports from multiple informants (caregivers, teachers, caseworkers).
rule_outs: Autism Spectrum Disorder (pervasive deficits in social reciprocity and restricted/repetitive behaviors).
Depression or anxiety disorders with social withdrawal but without attachment disruption.

core: Rarely seeks comfort from caregivers when distressed.
Rarely responds to comfort when distressed.
Unexplained irritability, sadness, or fearfulness in nonthreatening interactions.

severity_levels.persistent: Symptoms present for more than 12 months.
severity_levels.severe: All symptoms present at high levels.

biological: Prenatal substance exposure or malnutrition (non-specific risk).
environmental: Institutional rearing with limited one-on-one interaction.

impact_on_life.school: Difficulty forming trusting relationships with teachers/peers.
impact_on_life.family: Strained caregiver–child relationship, high caregiver stress.
impact_on_life.social: Limited friendships; withdrawal from group activities.

psychotherapy: Attachment-based interventions such as Child–Parent Psychotherapy, Dyadic Developmental Psychotherapy, or Attachment and Biobehavioral Catch-up.
Parent–child interaction coaching to improve caregiver responsiveness.
caregiver_support: Consistent, sensitive caregiving with predictable routines.
Respite and support services for foster/adoptive families.
medications: Address comorbid conditions (e.g., SSRIs for anxiety/depression, stimulants for ADHD) as appropriate.
care_coordination: Work with child welfare, mental health, medical, and educational teams.
Ensure stable placements and adequate caregiver training.

treatment_goals: Increase child’s ability to seek and accept comfort from caregivers.
Enhance emotional responsiveness and positive affect.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing social withdrawal to shyness without assessing early neglect/placement history.
Mislabeling as depression or ASD without considering attachment disruption.
overdiagnosis_factors: Diagnosing without history of extreme insufficient care.
Confusing normal stranger anxiety or cultural norms for pathology.
warning_signs: Child rarely approaches caregiver for comfort.
Limited emotional responsiveness even in positive settings.
Frequent unexplained irritability or sadness in safe contexts.
self_help_strategies: For caregivers: maintain consistent, sensitive, and nurturing care.
Engage in play and shared positive experiences daily.
Avoid punitive approaches; focus on building trust.

toddler_preschool: Minimal comfort-seeking; unresponsive to caregiver soothing; flat affect.
school_age: Continued reluctance to seek help; difficulty forming teacher relationships.
adolescence: Ongoing mistrust in close relationships; preference for emotional self-reliance.

real_life_examples: A 3-year-old who sits alone in daycare, never approaching the teacher when upset.
A 6-year-old in foster care who remains expressionless and unresponsive to praise or comfort.
A 14-year-old adopted from an institution who avoids physical affection and refuses to confide in caregivers.
content.when_to_seek_help: When a child rarely seeks or responds to comfort from caregivers, shows emotional withdrawal, or has a history of severe neglect or multiple caregiver changes.

positive_factors: Early placement in a stable, nurturing home.
challenging_factors: Caregiver burnout or lack of support.
